Order.title: Order
Order.description: Represents a material order placed by a construction company.

applicantName.description: Name of the person requesting the order.

projectName.description: Name of the construction project for which the order is placed.

paymentType.description: Type of payment for the order (Cash or Credit).

creditType.description: Type of credit payment (Weekly, Bi-weekly, Monthly). Only applicable if paymentType is Credit.

paymentMethod.description: Payment card or method used for credit payments.

definition.description: Stores material orders placed by construction companies.  Initially, all documents are stored here, regardless of the user. `orderId` is the unique identifier for each order.

firestore.reasoning:
Given the requirement for a front-end only application (no backend, direct Firestore access), and the focus on order management for a construction company, the simplest and most direct approach is to store orders in a single collection.  Since the application explicitly states the intent to add authentication later, we structure the database anticipating user-specific data.  This design anticipates the addition of user authentication, even though it's not immediately implemented. This supports future scalability and security when authentication is integrated.

**Authorization Independence (Future):** Currently, all data will be readable/writable in "sandbox" mode, but when authentication is added, the structure allows for simple role-based access control or ownership based on user ID by changing the security rules.

**QAPs:**
*   The segregation of all orders into a single `/orders` collection ensures a uniform security posture.  Initially open, future security rules can be applied to all documents within the collection.

Future improvements:

*   Adding user authentication and segmenting orders by user, e.g., `/users/{userId}/orders/{orderId}`.
*   Implementing proper security rules based on authentication and user roles.
*   Consider using subcollections for related data like order history or delivery logs, if the complexity increases.
